-KPouRkGrVFmiUg-OunS.description: Starting from a small dry goods store in Monroe, North Carolina, William Henry Belk opened retail stores in Charlotte and other communities across the southeast from the end of the nineteenth-century through the mid twentieth-century.
-KPouRkGrVFmiUg-OunS.name: William Henry Belk

-KPoup9lStpM2tZEZkPr.description: A prominent African American businessman and civic leader, Thaddeus (Thad) Lincoln Tate made a significant contribution to the Charlotte community in the early to mid twentieth-century.
-KPoup9lStpM2tZEZkPr.name: Thaddeus Tate

-KPousJ4PYHBxIW7RY3m.description: On May 19, 1775 a rider raced into Charlottetowne with news of the massacre of colonists by the British at the Battle of Concord and Lexington.
-KPousJ4PYHBxIW7RY3m.name: Captain Jack

-KPouxawWJ-S_IFuUqSG.description: Thomas “Kanawha” Spratt was among the earliest settlers in this part of the Carolinas. His father, also named Thomas Spratt, purchased land on Twelve Mile Creek, near present-day Fort Mill, SC, in 1750 and later added two plantations.
-KPouxawWJ-S_IFuUqSG.name: Thomas Spratt and King Haigler

-KPov2XF4D6WFKrlVMl0.description: Thomas Polk, one of the earliest settlers of Mecklenburg County, was a trained surveyor, a prosperous planter, and a local leader.
-KPov2XF4D6WFKrlVMl0.name: Thomas Polk
